Synopsis:
The film documents a part of the life of Phoolan Devi, the Bandit Queen who was once a terror of the Chambal Ravines. It traces her life from her marriage as a 12 year old to the point she negotiates her surrender and is jailed. It also brings out in vivid detail the life and customs in the ravines of Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh and rajasthan - an area that seems completely cut off from the rest of India.

Comments:
Shekhar Kapur's sympathetic portrayal of the life of the late Phoolan Devi is one of the best biographical films made in India, not the least for the superb acting by Seema Biswas in the lead role. Biswas is at once rustic, coarse and vulnerable and it is her ability to leave the city behind that makes her character so believable. She is supported by a splendid cast, where everyone seems to outdo others - a tribute to Sekhar Kapur really. I admired his ability to get the best out of children - children who play the role of abused youngsters.

Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan comes up with some memorable musical pieces. Cinematography of Ashok Mehta is a delight as he capture the wild beauty of the ravines but the best part is the editing by Renu Saluja..

Overall a fine film. A film worth watching.
